trans-unit.source: Add push notifications to your universal Windows 8.1 app | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Add push notifications to your universal Windows 8.1 app | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to send push notifications to your universal Windows 8.1 app from your .NET backend mobile service using Azure Notification Hubs.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to send push notifications to your universal Windows 8.1 app from your .NET backend mobile service using Azure Notification Hubs.

trans-unit.source: Add push notifications to your Mobile Services app
trans-unit.target: Add push notifications to your Mobile Services app

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to use Azure Mobile Services with a .NET backend to send push notifications to a universal Windows app.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to use Azure Mobile Services with a .NET backend to send push notifications to a universal Windows app.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial you enable push notifications using Azure Notification Hubs in a universal Windows app project.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial you enable push notifications using Azure Notification Hubs in a universal Windows app project.

trans-unit.source: When complete, your mobile service will send a push notification from the .NET backend to all registered Windows Store and Windows Phone Store apps each time a record is inserted in the TodoList table.
trans-unit.target: When complete, your mobile service will send a push notification from the .NET backend to all registered Windows Store and Windows Phone Store apps each time a record is inserted in the TodoList table.

trans-unit.source: The notification hub that you create is free with your mobile service, can be managed independent of the mobile service, and can be used by other applications and services.
trans-unit.target: The notification hub that you create is free with your mobile service, can be managed independent of the mobile service, and can be used by other applications and services.

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to use the tooling in Visual Studio Professional 2013 with Update 3 to add support for push notifications from Mobile Services to a universal Windows app.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to use the tooling in Visual Studio Professional 2013 with Update 3 to add support for push notifications from Mobile Services to a universal Windows app.

trans-unit.source: The same steps can be used to add push notifications from Mobile Services to a Windows Store or Windows Phone Store 8.1 app.
trans-unit.target: The same steps can be used to add push notifications from Mobile Services to a Windows Store or Windows Phone Store 8.1 app.

trans-unit.source: To add push notifications to a Windows Phone 8 or Windows Phone Silverlight 8.1 app, see this version of <link><linkText>Get started with push notifications in Mobile Services</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To add push notifications to a Windows Phone 8 or Windows Phone Silverlight 8.1 app, see this version of <link><linkText>Get started with push notifications in Mobile Services</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial, you need the following:
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial, you need the following:

trans-unit.source: An active <link><linkText>Microsoft Store account</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: An active <link><linkText>Microsoft Store account</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <html></html>Visual Studio Community 2013<html></html>.
trans-unit.target: <html></html>Visual Studio Community 2013<html></html>.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Register your app for push notifications
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Register your app for push notifications

trans-unit.source: 6.
trans-unit.target: 6.

trans-unit.source: Browse to the \Services\MobileServices\your_service_name project folder, open the generated push.register.cs code file, and inspect the UploadChannel method that registers the device's channel URL with the notification hub.
trans-unit.target: Browse to the \Services\MobileServices\your_service_name project folder, open the generated push.register.cs code file, and inspect the UploadChannel method that registers the device's channel URL with the notification hub.

trans-unit.source: 7.
trans-unit.target: 7.

trans-unit.source: Open the shared App.xaml.cs code file and notice that a call to the new UploadChannel method was added in the OnLaunched event handler.
trans-unit.target: Open the shared App.xaml.cs code file and notice that a call to the new UploadChannel method was added in the OnLaunched event handler.

trans-unit.source: This makes sure that registration of the device is attempted whenever the app is launched.
trans-unit.target: This makes sure that registration of the device is attempted whenever the app is launched.

trans-unit.source: 8.
trans-unit.target: 8.

trans-unit.source: Repeat the previous steps to add push notifications to the Windows Phone Store app project, then in the shared App.xaml.cs file, remove the extra call to UploadChannel and the remaining #if...#endif conditional wrapper.
trans-unit.target: Repeat the previous steps to add push notifications to the Windows Phone Store app project, then in the shared App.xaml.cs file, remove the extra call to UploadChannel and the remaining #if...#endif conditional wrapper.

trans-unit.source: Both projects can now share a single call to UploadChannel.
trans-unit.target: Both projects can now share a single call to UploadChannel.

trans-unit.source: You can also simplify the generated code by unifying the #if...#endif wrapped MobileServiceClient definitions into a single unwrapped definition used by both versions of the app.
trans-unit.target: You can also simplify the generated code by unifying the #if...#endif wrapped MobileServiceClient definitions into a single unwrapped definition used by both versions of the app.

trans-unit.source: Now that push notifications are enabled in the app, you must update the mobile service to send push notifications.
trans-unit.target: Now that push notifications are enabled in the app, you must update the mobile service to send push notifications.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Update the service to send push notifications
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Update the service to send push notifications

trans-unit.source: The following steps update the existing TodoItemController class to send a push notification to all registered devices when a new item is inserted.
trans-unit.target: The following steps update the existing TodoItemController class to send a push notification to all registered devices when a new item is inserted.

trans-unit.source: You can implement similar code in any custom <link><linkText>ApiController</linkText><title></title></link>, <link><linkText>TableController</linkText><title></title></link>, or anywhere else in your backend services.
trans-unit.target: You can implement similar code in any custom <link><linkText>ApiController</linkText><title></title></link>, <link><linkText>TableController</linkText><title></title></link>, or anywhere else in your backend services.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html> Enable push notifications for local testing
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html> Enable push notifications for local testing

trans-unit.source: The remaining steps in this section are optional.
trans-unit.target: The remaining steps in this section are optional.

trans-unit.source: They allow you to test your app against your mobile service running on a local computer.
trans-unit.target: They allow you to test your app against your mobile service running on a local computer.

trans-unit.source: If you plan to test push notifications using the mobile service running in Azure, you can just skip to the last section.
trans-unit.target: If you plan to test push notifications using the mobile service running in Azure, you can just skip to the last section.

trans-unit.source: This is because the Add Push Notification wizard already configured your app to connect to your service running in Azure.
trans-unit.target: This is because the Add Push Notification wizard already configured your app to connect to your service running in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Never use a production mobile service for testing and development work.
trans-unit.target: Never use a production mobile service for testing and development work.

trans-unit.source: Always publish your mobile service project to a separate staging service for testing.
trans-unit.target: Always publish your mobile service project to a separate staging service for testing.

trans-unit.source: 5.
trans-unit.target: 5.

trans-unit.source: Open the shared App.xaml.cs project file and locate any the lines of code that create a new instance of the [MobileServiceClient] class to access the mobile service running in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Open the shared App.xaml.cs project file and locate any the lines of code that create a new instance of the [MobileServiceClient] class to access the mobile service running in Azure.

trans-unit.source: 6.
trans-unit.target: 6.

trans-unit.source: Comment-out this code and add code that creates a new [MobileServiceClient] of the same name but using the URL of the local host in the constructor, similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: Comment-out this code and add code that creates a new [MobileServiceClient] of the same name but using the URL of the local host in the constructor, similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: Using this [MobileServiceClient], the app will connect to the local service instead of the version hosted in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Using this [MobileServiceClient], the app will connect to the local service instead of the version hosted in Azure.

trans-unit.source: When you want to switch back and run app against the mobile service hosted in Azure, change back to the original [MobileServiceClient] definitions.
trans-unit.target: When you want to switch back and run app against the mobile service hosted in Azure, change back to the original [MobileServiceClient] definitions.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html> Test push notifications in your app
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html> Test push notifications in your app

trans-unit.source: <html></html> <html></html>Next steps
trans-unit.target: <html></html> <html></html>Next steps

trans-unit.source: This tutorial demonstrated the basics of enabling a Windows Store app to use Mobile Services and Notification Hubs to send push notifications.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial demonstrated the basics of enabling a Windows Store app to use Mobile Services and Notification Hubs to send push notifications.

trans-unit.source: Next, consider completing the next tutorial, [Send push notifications to authenticated users], which shows how to use tags to send push notifications from a Mobile Service to only an authenticated user.
trans-unit.target: Next, consider completing the next tutorial, [Send push notifications to authenticated users], which shows how to use tags to send push notifications from a Mobile Service to only an authenticated user.
